description: From Middle English knappen (verb) and knappe (“strike”) (noun), an onomatopoeia.

verbs.description: knap (third-person singular simple present knaps, present participle knapping, simple past and past participle knapped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shape a brittle material having conchoidal fracture, usually a mineral (flint, obsidian, chert etc.), by breaking away flakes, often forming a sharp edge or point.

examples: Some entered the ring in very bad condition, and immediately got a-piping, like hot mutton pies - fell on their own blows, and knapped it every round, till they shewed the white feather and bolted.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, dialect) To bite; to bite off; to break short.
examples: He breaketh the bow, and knappeth the spear in sunder.

entries.meaning: To make a sound of snapping.
examples: Press back the head of the Femur into its Acetabulum , and it will knap in

description: From Middle English knappe (“knob”), from Old English cnæp, akin to cnotta (“knot”).

entries.meaning: A protuberance; a swelling; a knob.

examples: the highest part and knap of the same Iland
